ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learned more about piano.
Vocal technique, sight reading, language skills
I learned how to improve my breathing technique and how to practice efficiently.
better vocal technique, expansion of personal rep
I learned how to play better and interpret musicality in different ways.
I took voice lessons, and learned some good warmup drills and techniques.
Learned how to better regulate breathing, control vibrato, clarify intonation, and connect with music during performance
How to become more and more my own artist who will eventually teach myself.
I continued to improve my skills on the cello, refining my repertoire and techniques.
I really appreciated the opportunity to delve deeper into some new repertoire this semester, plan for my recital this December, and continue working on Sevcik bowing etudes.
Improved technical and musical abilities

I took weekly one-on-one percussion lessons with Makana Medeiros, a graduate student at the Yale School of Music. I learned helpful techniques relating to percussion playing, and I feel I have improved a lot.
I improved my general skills as a clarinetist and a musician through learning different approaches to solve problems related to musicianship, artistry, and technique.
how to essentially "teach myself", listening to my playing and intentionally analyzing for what can be improved, learning new repertoire i'd have never touched in high school

I deepened my connection with my own voice and learned many classical techniques. As part of this, I learned how to practice daily in a way that keeps my voice healthy and ready for performance throughout the semester. I also feel I learned about the artistic values of operatic singing, and gained a deeper appreciation for how to listen to the music: what techniques I can pinpoint, where singers are embellishing vs. following the text, important elements of diction I wouldn't have picked up on, etc.
Singing technique for the purpose of solo performance.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Personalized and helpful for supporting other music opportunities at Yale!
regular meeting times
Easy and nice to learn voice lessons
I think building in practice time would be more helpful for scheduling when to practice (ie give us a slot each week at the music school)

Strengths: you put in what you get out, voice lessons are an easy credit if thats what you're looking for. I was hoping for serious instruction and was disappointed. 
Weaknesses: voice lessons are incredibly disorganized. I didn't know we had to learn three songs (I was told two) until a week or two before final jury. Further, we weren't given a jury date until a week before, and we were not provided time to rehearse with the pianist beforehand (we had to find our own accompanist if we wanted to practice). My voice teacher was also not great, and tried to get me to use unhealthy vocal techniques (belting higher than I could, told me to "sing from my throat"). Prof. Baty was hard to reach, but very nice.

The lessons program is really nice and helped me improve my playing a lot this semester! I wish that the professors at YSM for certain instruments were less limited in being able to teach only graduate studentsI think the undergraduate music department could benefit from more access to the school of music in general and especially the professors.
Its great
No complaints!
The chance to work one on one with Professor Sharp is a truly wonderful opportunity.

I think the flexibility of this course is where its value lies. I was able to work with my private teacher on whatever was musically pertinent without the need to prepare for a final jury or any external motivators other than a love for music.
Weekly one-on-one lessons at the Yale School of Music are a phenomenal, unique experience that Yale has to offer. No immediate weaknesses come to mind.

I think this course is a great way to allow students to take music lessons for free. The only thing I might change is giving the option to increase the number of lessons as 10 can occasionally feel a bit restrictive.

the class being 1-on-1 is both a strength and weakness, since more engagement with the professor comes with less engagement with peers that have similar interests; i'd advocate for events/studio recitals with the other students from the same teacher (or it can be with different teachers and/or instruments)

Strengths: one-on-one instruction with a lovely graduate student, continuous check in, accomodated me even as someone who had very little experience with classical singing.
Weaknesses: would have loved more robust feedback at the conclusion of the course... I was happy to have passed but it would've been nice to have some things to reflect on/work on so that I can continue to grow in the next semester.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, music lessons for credit are a wonderful way to improve your musicianship skills.
I loved this course!! Definitely audition for lessons - there is nothing to lose!!
Yes, especially if youd want to continue playing an instrument. Having an instructor is helpful.
Potentially, depending on their teacher
Yes! Wonderful way to learn singing techniques in a relaxed environment
Yes its a good way to keep up the level of skill of playing
I think your experience depends strongly on what teacher you are paired with. I didn't get lucky, but some people have great experiences.

Yes! It is a really great way to get involved with the music department. Lessons really are what you make them so I would not recommend taking this class if you know you won't have time to practice, because then it will feel like a waste of both your and your teacher's time.
Its great for both experienced and inexperienced musicians. Most teachers are classically trained but are open to a lot of musical theater and pop music.
Yes, I would. The music lessons are essential for improvement of one's playing, and the instruction is given at a very high level.
I would definitely recommend this course to anyone who is wanting to pursue violin in college and really take the time to practice and improve.
Yes, I would recommend taking private lessons to any student who wants to continue studying their instrument at a high level.
YES
I would highly recommend this course to any musically inclined student who would like to improve at their respective instrument (or voice).
Yes, absolutely, if you would like to take free music lessons with a Yale School of Music student.
yes! taking private lessons was such an easy way to keep up with my instrument throughout the busy semester, and it helped me build a connection with the graduate school as an undergraduate
Yes! Take lessons for credit!

If you want to train your voice and learn a lot, TAKE THIS COURSE! Everyone I engaged with was very welcoming and friendly. Besides, it's not the trickiest credit if you're at all familiar with singing, so it's a nice way to supplement a busy term.
Yes. Lessons speak for themselves... certainly an invaluable experience for the classical singer.
